Red spaces give teams 30 seconds to guess 2 multi-syllable rhyming pairs (sincere cashier, construction reduction).

Grey spaces are "showdown" spaces, in which each team nominates one team member to compete. The chosen players are given one word and must alternate naming as many rhyming words as possible, until one player either repeats a word, gives a word that doesn't rhyme, or takes more than 5 seconds.

The first team to reach the "high noon" space at the top of the board and win a final showdown is declared the champion.

70090.name: Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs Game
70090.description: This is a card game with four suits - Triangles, Circles, Squares and Stars. The miniature cards feature illustrations from Snow White - Snow White, each of the dwarfs, the Huntsman, the Wicked Queen, the Witch, the Prince. Points are scored by laying down runs of cards. Points are lost if you then have to pick up tricks.

70091.name: Pinocchio Card Game
70091.description:
This is a trick-taking game for four players.

From the back of the box:
Each player is dealt 11 cards and the last 4 cards are laid in the center of the table. The player to the left of the dealer estimates how many tricks he thinks he can take, and the highest bidder may substitute any or all of the 4 cards in the center for his 4 lowest cards. Taking the four lowest cards from his hand he lays them down in front of him as one trick and then leads a card. Each of the other players in turn plays a higher card if possible and the one who plays the card with the highest number takes the trick. The winner then leads a card from his hand. If the highest bidder doesn't get the number of tricks he bid, he will have that amount deducted from his score. All other players get one point for each trick they take. The first player to get 50 points wins the game.

The miniature cards have illustrations on them from Pinocchio. The instructions are written on the back of the box. The cards range in number from 1 to 11 with fewer cards for each number as the number increases:

7 copies of #1 featuring Monstro
6 copies of #2 featuring Lampwick
6 copies of #3 featuring The Coachman
5 copies of #4 featuring Stromboli
5 copies of #5 featuring Fox and Cat
4 copies of #6 featuring Figaro
4 copies of #7 featuring Cleo
4 copies of #8 featuring Jiminy Cricket
4 copies of #9 featuring Geppetto
2 copies of #10 featuring The Blue Fairy
1 copy of #11 featuring Pinocchio

The illustrations are copyright W.D.P. [Walt Disney Pictures]. This is Volume 2 in a series.

70092.description:
This books describes 40 battle scenarios during the ancient period, from Acragas in 406BC to Yarmuk in 636 AD. Each scenario is given on one page. Troop order of battle is described for use by De Bellis Antiquitatis/Multitudinus (DBA/M). The author gives the number of men represented by each stand, so it should be simple to adapt the scenarios to other rule sets.

Example: Early Macedonian army at Crocus Plain:
"20000 Foot: 8 Auxilia (5 I(I), 3 R(O)), 6 Psiloi I(O), 6 Spear R(O)
3000 Mounted: 1 Knight R(F), 2 Cavalry R(O)
1 General Knight R(F)"
70092.name: Ancient Historical Battles, Volume 2

70093.name: Powers (Core): Core Combat
70093.description: From Web Site:You ready for combat? If not, then consider this 17 card pack your "Basic Training"! Packed with hard-hitting Powers that will make you a more versatile and deadly combatant in the world of Untold! All the basic combat moves you're used to; and a whole list of new ones to boot!

70094.name: Powers (Core): Basic Traits
70094.description: from the Web SiteAmp up your character! This 35 card deck has everything you need to alter, grow, or supplement your Untold character. Using Untold's unique Swapping mechanic, these Power cards allow you to change your character's Agility, Intellect, Strength, or countless other traits!

70095.name: Powers (Core): Basic Skills
70095.description: From the Web Site:You got skills? If not, this 35(+) card deck can give them to you: tons of Power cards that give your Untold character all of the basic skills they'll need. Be a better Climber, Linguist, Actor or max out your Arcane Knowledge. You're limited only by your imagination!

70096.description:
This game basically re-enacts the tale of the three little pigs. Players cooperate in building the brick house and avoiding the wolf until they are all safe inside the brick house.

Play is basic roll-and-move, with each pig having a die of its own color. Die results are either move 1, 2, or 3 spaces (in either direction), or move the wolf, or run away to one of the three houses.

The wolf moves clockwise in jumps that can sweep up any piggies he lands on or passes. Pigs that are caught are put in the cook pot. The other little pigs can rescue pigs in the pot if they land on one of the cauldron spaces and roll a die successfully.

Pigs are safe when they are in a house.

At the beginning of the game, the brick house is not yet built. It has four pieces. When a pig lands on the brick house space, he or she can add one piece to the house. Once the brick house is completed, the pigs can occupy it. Once all three pigs are in the brick house, they win. If the wolf captures all three pigs, however, they lose.
70096.name: Woolfy

70097.description:
from publisher's site

In the reign of Louis XIV, Pierre-Paul Riquet, Superintendent of the Army and a brilliant engineer, proposed the idea of a canal system using water from the Montagne Noire in the Massif Central. Between 1665 and his death in 1680, Riquet was completely anbsorbed by the planning, financing and construction of his canal system. Sections of it, including the Canal de Garonne, remained unfinished until the 19th century.

You can relive the adventure of building the canal, section by section, between Grisolles and Valence d'Agen in the heart of the Tarn-et-Garonne. Each player is an engineer who must use their best workers to build the greatest length of the Arriala (cannal in the Occitan language of southern France). You can move all workers, but only those on your team will gain you fame points for completing sections. The placement of your workers when construction is completed is critical. Your aim is to have the most workers on a stretch of canal when it is completed. Ties are broken in favour of the player placed third. It is also possible to build locks to alter sections of the canal and create new ones. However, the number of points awarded depends on the length of the section: a lock may win you a majority, but at what price?

Points can also be scored for building structures, though this sacrifices a worker (five maximum per player) for the rest of the game. What's more, your expertise also extends to cultivating the vines that make this region famous and will bring you valuable points when the game ends.
70097.name: Arriala: Canal de Garonne

70098.name: Monster Coliseum
70098.description:
From the back of the book:

Monster coliseum details dozens of creatures for RuneQuestII, placing them in the exciting backdrop of the arenas and amphitheatres where gladiators and fearsome beasts do battle for sport and glory.

Each creature features notes on how it fights along with its preferred combat styles and manouvres.

The coliseum itself is also explored with notes on structure, personnel and special events: chariot races through to pitched battles.

No longer are creatures simply there as sword fodder or a series of numbers. Monster Coliseum brings life and death to your RQII campaign!

70099.description:
This game is set in a Pippi Longstocking theme and is intended to be a used for multiplication training of children.

The games consists of two decks of cards. One deck with simple multiplication questions like 5x5 or 1x3. The other deck is answer cards with text like =25 or =3. At the start of the game, each player is dealt a number of question. The answer cards are placed in a heap on the table. The goal of the game is to score points by making pairs of question cards and answer cards.

Pluttifikation is Pippis word for multiplication.
70099.name: Pippi pluttifikationsspel

70100.name: Aspects (Core): Basic Aspects
70100.description: From the website:Time to get boosted! If your character just isn't cutting it, then this 17 Aspect Deck is for you! Everything you need to increase your Body, Mind and/or Soul! Using Untold's unique Swapping mechanic, you can change your character's core ON THE FLY - no other RPG can do that!

70101.name: Races (Core): L'na: Dawns and Twilights
70101.description: From the website:No cuddly teddy bears here! Nothing less than 17 new L'na core race cards: 9 new Dawns and 8 new Twilights that you can play or meet on the battlefield with Untold: Battle! This deck has everything from winged defenders of snowy peaks to mysterious spider-snake mentalists!

70102.name: Races (Core): Klik: Rollers and Tripods
70102.description: From the website:Time to get steamed up! This rockin' "steampunk"-filled booster delivers 17 new Klik core race cards: 8 Rollers/9 Tripods that you can trade, play as characters, or use in your next Battle match! Everything from Tripod "Scouts" to Roller "Mad Scientists" await your commands!

70103.name: Races (Core): Apocs: High-breds and Churls
70103.description: from the website:Super soldiers surplus! This slammin' booster contains 17 new Apoc core race cards: 8 High-bred/9 Churls just waiting to be played in the Untold RPG, traded, or used in Untold: Battle! Tough High-bred from across the ruined globe alongside exotic Churl from the Arctic to Africa.

70104.name: Banes (Core): Basic Banes
70104.description: From the website:Bring out the Banes--players hate 'em, GM's love 'em! As part of the core set of Untold cards, Bane cards are those cards that come out when bad things happen, when a Character suffers a condition: Surprised, Blind, Immobile, Dazed, etc. all you need do is slap down a Bane card.

70105.name: Banes (Core): Basic Drains
70105.description: From the website;ake drains a cinch! With this pack of 35(+) Drain Cards, you can track all of the negative conditions your character will experience at the wicked hands of your GM! In Untold, your character may suffer, but YOU don't have to!

70106.name: Hostile Hand (Core): GM's Minions
70106.description: From the website:This nest of nasties is everything a GM needs to get started in the world of Untold! Friends and foes alike abound in this GM Minion pack: 35 ready to use minions! Inside, you'll find everything from Externals to Undead, Churl Barbarians to Living Lightning!

70107.name: Iconic Character: Toa
70107.description: From the website:You are the "Favored Son" of Ahomana Ahohako, a remote, volcanic island chain amid the shattered remains of an apocalyptic Earth. You are the fury of the eruption; the strength of the mountains tempered only by the endurance of the sea. You are Toa and Untold rewards await you!

70108.name: Iconic Character: Sarge
70108.description: From the website:Fall in MAGGOT! Just 'cause I'm a lady doesn't mean ya don't hafta call me Sir! I'll be yer NCO and if yer lucky, you MIGHT get the honor to call me Sarge, but don't bet on it, maggots! I've got the know-how, skills, an' the gear and I WILL lead ya into the Untold!

70109.name: Iconic Character: 201132
70109.description: From the website:A scion of the Great Machine, you're a being of steam, gears, pistons and pulleys. Your designation is 201132, ("Roller" to non-Klik) and you're endowed with awesome mobility, intelligence and versatility. Your heart-gear thrums as you rocket into the Untold!

70110.name: Iconic Character: Buzzsaw
70110.description: From the website:Founded by the Great Machine, you're a thing of pig-iron, rivets, pistons and steam. Everyone calls you Buzzsaw, it's easy to see why. You explore the Untold to find fuel for the Great Machine. Your strength and massive, whirling saws come in handy for that!

70111.description:
Everywhere in the galaxy enormous worms are crunching and eating themselfes through the universe, sometimes even the "eternal carrot gods" will intervine.

Galactic worms is a 2-6 player fast-paced games where there can only be one worm when the universe is totally destroyed.

Aim of the game: each player starts with some worm parts and tries to eat as many planets as they can, and play out carrotcards/battlecards/"eternal carrot god" cards against each other.

When all planets are eaten it´s time to kill of other players until there is only one left.

When you destroy enemies you get some of their planets, when only one player is left it´s time to count who has most points. Count: eaten body parts, planets, and the length of the winner worm in play.

Game components:
1 psychedelic map 64x64cm ( with art by Peter Stenberg)
2 dice, more than 30 worm tiles, 45+ carrot cards, planets. + bonus stuff included.

Expansion is also planned at the end of 2010
Also tournament rules + experience point system will be included.
70111.name: Galactic worms

70114.name: The Tarot of the Black Cat
70114.description: Each player has the tarot cards on hand. The start player declare a number from 1 to 22. It is discarded by the player that has the card of the number. The turn is played clockwise. If the player is no hand, the player is removed in this game. The last player is the winner.

70115.name: EMPIRES: Fate of a World
70115.description:
How does an empire grow from a nomadic tribe of spear-wielding cave people into the greatest civilization of all? Is an empire forged though might and battle? Through enlightenment and culture? Or through the amassing of great and undeniable wealth?

The course of history is up to you! Guide your empire from its beginnings into a futuristic nation of leaders! Wipe out any who stand in your way, or absorb their territories into yours!

EMPIRES: FATE OF A WORLD is a strategy game for 2 to 4 players where each player represents a civilization in its infancy, owning nothing more than a small settlement and an explorer unit. Through the use of Development Cards (Archery, Railroads, Robotics, and the like), players sculpt their civilizations. Over time, settlements become cities, explorers give way to armies, and eventually, one Empire will emerge as the greatest of all!

EMPIRES: FATE OF A WORLD is played out on a world map board, with wooden tokens representing settlements, cities, and units. In addition, each player has a development mat where he or she plays Development Cards that shape the Empire. How a player achieves victory is completely up to them: Wealth, Culture, or Might.

Featuring a combination of skill, strategy, and luck, EMPIRES: FATE OF A WORLD is perfect for anyone with their sights set on ruling the world!

Please visit the game site for more details!
http://www.thegamecrafter.com/games/empires-fate-of-a-world

70116.description:
For half a millennium, a group of ghosts have been growing quite weary of one another's company in an old Scottish castle.

Since they are thoroughly bored with the social scene of the stony structure, each ghost secretly wishes to escape the castle and go on wild adventures. Unfortunately, the ghosts are trapped there.

Suddenly, an opportunity arises! They discover three glimmering magical portals that they might be able to use to find freedom. Desperation sets in quickly, because they know the portals won't be open long, so the ghosts scramble and jostle one another, trying to slip through the portals while they have the chance. They certainly don't want to see each other's ethereal faces for another 500 years!

COMPONENTS:

18 Ghosts includes:


A board depicting an old Scottish castle with 25 rooms (5×5) and one large dungeon.
18 ghosts in 2 types and 3 colors (3 for each color and type).
3 portals, one of each color.


GOAL OF THE GAME:

Both players try to help their ghosts escape from the castle.

In order to win the game, be the first to have a red ghost, a blue ghost, and a yellow ghost outside the castle.

When this happens, the game ends immediately. That player is the winner.
70116.name: 18 Ghosts

70121.name: Bizzaro Games' Black Powder Rules
70121.description:
User summary

Bizzaro Games' Black Powder Rules is a free preview of the firearms and artillery rules from the SpirosBlaak supplement.

It includes:


Skills
Feats
Black powder weapon attributes
Sample firearm, artillery, and grenade descriptions
Masterwork firearms
Black powder combat rules

70122.name: Creatures from the Depths
70122.description:
(From the back of the book)

Kidnapping a princess and holding her to ransom is a risky business in the City of Salos, where the Usurper’s guards are everywhere crushing rebellion.

As Edrix, Prince of Shadows, you must snatch her from the Usurper’s iron grasp and give your pursuers the slip as you flee through the uncharted world of tombs and sewers beneath the City!

But which of the Creatures from the Depths is friend, and which is foe? You will need to have your wits about you, and use the book’s unique system of clues and skills, to create your own role-playing adventure, and come out of it alive...

70123.name: Mean Streets
70123.description:
(From the back Cover)

Can you survive long enough in the Mean Streets of Salos to wrest your crown from the Usurper’s grasp?

As Edrix, Prince of Shadows, you must face great peril... Will you fight, talk or tumble your way through? The choice is yours, as you create your own fantasy epic.

Only our unique system of skills and clues can aid you as you battle your way through the tangled streets of Salos, city of adventure!

70124.name: Target Gotland
70124.description:
This is a Cold War era game depicting the hypothetical Soviet invasion of this strategically located Swedish island in the Baltic Sea. Includes five small (8.5" x 11") unmounted mapsheets and 300 unmounted counters. Originally published in issue #6 of the Swedish wargame magazine Combat!.

(c)1978 by Wellington Wargames of Kisa, Sweden.

70125.name: Warsaw Rising
70125.description:
This wargame depicts the struggle between the Polish patriots of the Armja Krajowa and the German garrison in 1944. The 120 units in the countermix include the Hermann Goring Division, SS Cossacks, and wire guided mini-tanks called Goliaths. The 23" x 17" map represents Warsaw and the suburbs on both sides of the Vistula River.

Combat can be affected by sewers, Stukas, and massive railway artillery pieces. The Poles must capture key locations to gather additional weapons from the Nazi occupation troops. The major Polish objective is to capture a bridge across the Vistula and link up their scattered froces.

70126.name: The Pre-Dreadnought Era 1870-1905
70126.description:
This is a naval combat game designed to recreate the tactics used in the transitional period of fleet actions that spanned the era between sail and steam.

The only scenario provided in the rules covers the decisive 1898 battle of Santiago during the Cuban Campaign. The designer suggests that players consult reference works like "Jane's Fighting Ships" to create additional scenarios. The battle system uses dice and hits are determined by armor thickness and the penetrating power of the projectile.

Includes a map, 60 counters, and a 24 page rule booklet.

70127.name: Chocobo's Dungeon 2
70127.description:
"Chocobo's Dungeon 2, originally released in Japan as Chocobo no Fushigina Dungeon 2​ (チョコボの不思議なダンジョン2, Chokobo no Fushigina Danjon 2, lit. "Chocobo's Mysterious Dungeon 2") is the 1998 PlayStation sequel to 1997's Chocobo no Fushigina Dungeon. Unlike its predecessor, the game, titled Chocobo's Dungeon 2, was released in North America in late 1999. In Chocobo's Dungeon 2, the player controls a chocobo named Chocobo. The game is part of the Fushigi no Dungeon series. The game was planned to be released for Bandai's WonderSwan Color handheld in 1999, but it was apparently cancelled.

In this game, the mazes for the dungeons are randomly-generated, though certain portions have specific patterns, such as the mazes and rooms in Cid's tower. This means that each time the player enters the same dungeon, the path through the maze will be different, although the same items and monsters will be encountered. If played slowly, there are some small gaps near the edges of these mazes and in certain corners if approached correctly Chocobo can pass through them and skip to a later part of the level."

Source: Wikipedia, "Chocobo_(series)," available under the CC-BY-SA License.

70128.name: Gemischtes Doppel 2
70128.description:
The Süddeutsche Zeitung Magazin features pairs of illustrated spoonerisms and similar transpositions as a regular humour columnn. When a collection of these "nearly matching pairs" was published in 2006, the publishers chose the format of a Memory-type game rather than a coffee table book. This 2009 publication is the second such collection.

Matching pairs in the Memory game involves finding the related words printed on the cards. Since each card has its own illustration, the pictures on two matching cards will usually have nothing in common. For instance, where "Goldfinger" (gold fingers) is illustrated with a close-up of the hands of a golden statue, the matching "Golfdinger" (golf thingies) card displays a pile of golf tees.

70129.name: Chocobo Racing

videogamefranchise.6399: The Best (Best Selling PlayStation Games, JP)

70129.description:
"Chocobo Racing, known in Japan as Chocobo Racing: Genkai e no Rōdo (チョコボレーシング 〜幻界へのロード〜, lit. "Chocobo Racing: Road to the Spirit World") is a racing game for the PlayStation game console. The game was developed by Square Co., creators of the Final Fantasy series of video games. The game was first released in Japan in March 1999. North American and European releases followed that year.

As a formulaic kart racer, Chocobo Racing is often compared to Mario Kart and Crash Team Racing. The game's star and namesake is the Chocobo, the mascot of the Final Fantasy series. Other figures from the game series, such as Mog the Moogle, the Black Mage, and Cid, fill out the all-Final Fantasy cast. Most of the game's soundtrack is composed using tunes from previous Final Fantasy titles.

The game was later released in Japan alongside Chocobo Stallion and Dice de Chocobo as part of the Chocobo Collection. On December 20, 2001, the game was re-released individually as part of the PSone Books series. The game received generally average reviews, citing its low quality in several aspects of gameplay."

Source: Wikipedia, "Chocobo_Racing," available under the CC-BY-SA License.

70130.name: Battle For Rome: Anzio-Cassino 1944
70130.description:
This operational level WWII game shows all of the attempts to crack the German defenses in Italy from December 1943 to May 1944. The board covers the Anzio Beachead and the Gustav Line. The game includes full color maps and 420 die-cut counters. Contains several scenarios with a complete package of set-up sheets.

According to the game insert, only 100 copies of this game was made.

70131.name: Super Mario Kart

videogamefranchise.6395: Player's Choice (Best Selling Nintendo Games, US & EU)

70131.description:
User summary:

Super Mario kart for the SNES is the game that started the succesful Mario Kart series. The game was developed and released by Nintendo. It was published in 1992 for the SNES and in 2009 for the Virtual Console. It uses Mode 7 graphics to create the 3D feel of the game. Characters from the Mario Universe race in karts against each other, using items to get an advantage over the other racers.

The game features 4 game modes, 20 different race tracks and 8 different drivers with unique driving styles (including: Mario, Luigi, Bowser and Donkey Kong jr).
The following modes are present in the game: Grand Prix, Match Race, Time Trial and Battle Mode.
In Grand Prix, the main mode of the game, one or two players can compete in three different speed classes: 50cc, 100cc and an unlockable 150cc. Each class is more difficult as the speed goes up as well as the aggressiveness of the opponents. There are four different cups to choose from: Mushroom Cup, Flower Cup, Star Cup and an unlockable Special Cup. Each cup consists of five tracks. The first four placed drivers in each race receive points for the cup. After four races the gold, silver and bronze is awarded.
In Match Race, two players can race against each other, selecting single races.
In Time Trial, a player can try to beat the best lap and total times for every race track. The times are stored in the card's battery backed memory.
In Battle Mode, two players compete against each other trying to burst the opponents three balloons, using items like banana peels, koopa shells and super stars. The battles take place on four Battle Mode-only maze-like tracks.

Every driver can carry one item at a time. Items are obtained by driving over 'question-mark'-tiles on the circuit. There are a number of different items, including shells, banana peels, mushrooms and lightning strikes. These items can be used to attack opponents, defend against attacks or to get a temporary boost. Apart from the items a player can also collect coins. The more coins, the higher the maximum speed. Coins are lost when hit by opponents attacks, falling of the track and bumping into other karts.
For the 20 different race tracks there are 7 different styles: Mario Circuit, Donut plains, Ghost Valley, Bowser Castle, Choco Island, Koopa Beach, Vanilla Lake and Rainbow Road.

Super Mario Kart has more of a racing feel compared to most of its sequels. It has a far less 'bash the leader'-feel as the items received are not so much determined by position in the race. Especially in the higher 150cc class it is absolutely essential to drive tight and know your way around the tracks in order to win. The Time Trial mode adds to that feel as well, as beating record times comes down to hundredths of a second in the case of competitive racing.

The game was very well received and sold eight million copies, becoming the third best-selling SNES game, after Super Mario World and Donkey Kong Country. The game is still regarded as one of the greatest games by many reviewers and considered a defining game in a number of ways: non-platforming games featuring the Mario cast, kart-racing games and the SNES-era in general.

70132.name: Wehrmacht
70132.description:
Subtitle: The War in Russia 1941-1945.

This is an epic strategic level game of the entire campaign fought by Germany and the Axis partners against the USSR. Includes 255 die-cut counters, a three-color map, and set up sheets for the various scenarios.

This zip-loc wargame was the first title published by Fusilier Games of Scotland.

70133.name: Mario Kart 64

videogamefranchise.6395: Player's Choice (Best Selling Nintendo Games, US & EU)

70133.description:
"Mario Kart 64​ (マリオカート64, Mario Kāto Rokujūyon) is a racing game developed and published by Nintendo for the Nintendo 64. It was released in 1996 in Japan and in 1997 in North America and Europe. On January 25, 2007, Mario Kart 64 was released on Nintendo's European Virtual Console service for the Wii. It was released on the American service on January 29, 2007, and in Japan on January 30, 2007.

Mario Kart 64 is the sequel to Super Mario Kart for the Super Nintendo Entertainment System. Changes from the original include the move to 3D computer graphics and the inclusion of four-player support. Players take control of characters from the Mario universe, who race around a variety of tracks with items that can either harm opponents or aid the user. The move to three-dimensional graphics allowed for track features not possible with the original game's Mode 7 graphics, such as changes in elevation, bridges, walls, and pits. However, the characters and items remained 2D pre-rendered sprites.

Music for the game was composed by Kenta Nagata. The introduction music for Mario Kart 64, which is loosely based on the original Super Mario Kart theme tune, was remixed and used in the music video game Dance Dance Revolution: Mario Mix for the Nintendo GameCube. The game was critically well received by critics and was a best seller. Mario Kart 64 was one of the first games in the series to feature Charles Martinet as the voice of both Luigi and Wario. It also features the voices of Isaac Marshall as Toad."

Source: Wikipedia, "Mario_Kart_64," available under the CC-BY-SA License.

70134.name: Mario Kart Super Circuit

videogamefranchise.6395: Player's Choice (Best Selling Nintendo Games, US & EU)

videogamehonor.29705: 2002 D.I.C.E. Best Handheld Game of the Year Nominee

70134.description:
"Mario Kart: Super Circuit, known in Japan as Mario Kart Advance (マリオカートアドバンス, Mario Kāto Adobansu), is a racing game developed and published by Nintendo for the Game Boy Advance in 2001. It was the first Mario Kart released on a handheld game system; in 2005, a second handheld Mario Kart game titled Mario Kart DS was released. It is the first Mario Kart game not to be developed by Nintendo EAD; instead, it was developed by Nintendo's Intelligent Systems division.

Super Circuit combines features from earlier Mario Kart games (Super Mario Kart and Mario Kart 64). In particular, it features the gameplay mechanics of the latter title and tracks from the former game. In the game, eight racers take to the tracks and race for first place."

Source: Wikipedia, "Mario_Kart:_Super_Circuit," available under the CC-BY-SA License.

70135.name: Mario Kart Double Dash!!

videogamehonor.31752: 2003 Game Critics Best Racing Game of the Year Nominee

70135.description:
"Mario Kart: Double Dash!! is a racing game developed by Nintendo Entertainment Analysis and Development and published by Nintendo for the Nintendo GameCube in 2003. The game is the fourth installment in the Mario Kart series, following Mario Kart: Super Circuit from 2001. It was succeeded by the console games Mario Kart DS and Mario Kart Wii in 2005 and 2008 respectively, and the arcade games in the Mario Kart Arcade GP series.

The game introduced a number of new gameplay features, most notably the inclusion of two riders per kart. Double Dash!! supports LAN play using the Nintendo GameCube Broadband Adapter, allowing 16 players to compete simultaneously. There are 20 characters to select from in total, with eleven of them being new to the series. A special item for each character has also been implemented.

Double Dash!! was generally well-received by critics; it attained an aggregated score of 87 out of 100 on Metacritic. Reviewers praised the graphics and the new gameplay features, but criticized the voice acting. It was also commercially successful, selling over 3.8 million copies in the United States, and over 802,000 copies in Japan."

Source: Wikipedia, "Mario_Kart:_Double_Dash‼," available under the CC-BY-SA License.

70136.name: Linebacker 2
70136.description: This is a strategic level wargame of the 1972 bombing campaign against North Vietnam. Includes one map and 150 counters. This game from Sweden originally appeared in issue #8 of "Combat" magazine.

70137.name: Mario Kart Arcade GP
70137.description:
"Mario Kart Arcade GP is an arcade-only iteration of Nintendo's Mario Kart series, developed by both Namco and Nintendo. Designed for the Triforce arcade board (also used for F-Zero AX), players can race as one of eleven characters in twenty-four tracks. On certain machines a player's data can be saved on a magnetic card, which can be inserted into the machine again later to retain unlocked items and records.

This game's arcade cabinet houses a camera that will take a photograph of the player's face. The photo can be customized and then will be displayed above the player's character during multiplayer races.

The game is noted for being the first Mario Kart to feature playable crossover characters: Namco's Pac-Man, Ms. Pac-Man and Blinky. The game received a sequel in 2007 in the form of Mario Kart Arcade GP 2."

Source: Wikipedia, "Mario_Kart_Arcade_GP," available under the CC-BY-SA License.

70138.name: Mario Kart DS

videogamehonor.31774: 2005 Game Critics Best Handheld Game of the Year Nominee

70138.description:
"Mario Kart DS (マリオカートDS) is a racing game developed and published by Nintendo. It was released for the Nintendo DS handheld game console in North America, Australia, and Europe in November 2005, and in Japan in December 2005. The game is the fifth installment in the Mario Kart series of video games, and the first to be playable via the Nintendo Wi-Fi Connection online service. Like other games in the series, Mario Kart DS features characters from the Mario series, and pits them against each other as they race in karts on tracks based on locations in the Mario series.

The game was well received, receiving an aggregated score of 91% from Metacritic. Praise focused on the game's graphics and gameplay, while criticism targeted its repetitive single-player mode. Mario Kart DS received several awards, including Editors' Choice Awards from GameSpot and IGN, G-Phoria's Best Handheld Game award, and IGN's Best Racing/Driving Game and Game of the Year awards for 2005. In the United States, Mario Kart DS was the best-selling handheld game in its first month of release, and also held that position the following month. Overall, Mario Kart DS is the sixth best-selling game for the Nintendo DS as of January 2009."

Source: Wikipedia, "Mario_Kart_DS," available under the CC-BY-SA License.

70139.name: Mario Kart Wii

videogamefranchise.11430: Nintendo Selects (Best Selling Wii Games, US & EU)

videogamehonor.31136: 2008 Spike Best Driving Game of the Year Nominee

70139.description:
User Summary:
Mario Kart returns to the Wii console. 24 playable characters (8 for each of the three weight classes), 6 karts and 6 bikes for each character, 32 different courses, multiple race speeds, 20 items, battle mode, mirrored options, time trials, auto and drift controls, and much more are included in this game. You can race against the computer to complete objectives and unlock characters/vehicles/modes and more. Once you are comfortable with the game, you can also jump online and race with up to 12 other players from around the world.

This game brings a lot of new content, but also updates many classic tracks and features for the Wii console. Most of the new features seem focused on new characters/vehicles and enhanced playing modes. Even if you've played the predecessors, there is a lot of new content and enjoyment packaged in this game. And if you want to drive with a wheel, it has that as well!

70140.name: Rush Hour U.S.A.: Atlanta Edition
70140.description:
The object of the game is to travel from work to your home neighborhood in Atlanta, collecting three different bartender business cards on the way. Along the way, players must avoid the police (and a potential DUI) and roadblocks created by the Department of Transportation and the City of Atlanta.

The game contains six cars, six matching plastic chips (to mark the home neighbohood), 40 bar break cards, 80 highway risk cards, 80 numbered bartender cards, and two dice.

Published by Aggressive Enterprises, Inc.

(Taken from the enclosed rules sheet).

70142.description:
Kokusai Sannin Shogi (International three-person chess) is a modern variant of Shogi (Japanese chess) for three players, created around 1930 by Tanigasaki Jisuke.

The game takes place on a board of 127 hexagonal cells. Each player controls a set of 18 pieces. The game allows for two players to enter an alliance against the third. If two players engage in a coordinated attack against the third, they are entered into an alliance automatically. The player not in an alliance gains a more powerful king piece and easier win conditions to counterbalance the alliance. As in other games in the chess family, the goal is to checkmate an opponent's king. A player not in an alliance need only checkmate one player to defeat both of them.

Unlike traditional games in the chess family, which have a thin military theme, kokusai sannin shogi has a thin political one, with pieces named after concepts such as public opinion, diplomacy and propaganda.

Incorporates information from: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sannin_shogi
70142.name: Kokusai Sannin Shogi

70143.name: Jazz King
70143.description:
Tagline:
"Hoping to use your eye for putting the right musicians together and counting on a bit of luck finding the right venues, you set out to create an empire of glitzy nightclubs, headline bands, and swinging music. The city is wide open. Welcome to Jazz King."

Jazz King is a Print & Play game of set collection and area control. In order for a player to place a venue on the board they must collect the necessary musicians to fill the venue. The more control a player exerts over a city block, via venues, the more points they earn.

Print & Play Components:
Game Board
Venue Tiles
Musician Cards
Event Cards

Additional Components for play:
84 playing bits/cubes (21 cubes in four colors).

70144.name: Creature Collection
70144.description:
From the back of the book:

"Ratfolk and Trogodons and Goblin Bears. Oh my!

From the evasive asaathi to the famed mithril golem, creatures frightening and wondrous are found throughout the lands of fantasy. Add to your arsenal of dread with more than 180 creatures ready to be added to your 4th Edition campaign. Dominated by the captivating damanshee, tricked by the crafty coal goblins, or paralyzed by the legacies of the slarecians, this tome captures the wonder, excitement, and uncertainty of new encounters and new monstrous foes.

Creature Collection for 4th Edition presents favourites from the best-selling d20 series, now updated and adapted to the latest rules."

70146.name: Bloodmaw's Marauders
70146.description:
User description:

Bloodmaw's Marauders is a convention scenario involving six orc pre-generated players attempting to retrieve a stolen banner. Originally run a at Gen Con 2001 by Richard Ioro II, it has been updated to the Second edition WFRP rules by Mikko Savolainen.

70147.name: The Lord of Lost Heart
70147.description:
'or, A Plague on Both Your Houses'
WFRP2 Scenario Contest 2009 Third Place.

From the introduction:

The Lord of Lost Heart pits the PCs against the forces of Nurgle in the prosperous village of Hohlesbruck. Two families, the wealthy Faulebrands and the noble Verlorens, are engulfed in the machinations of the Fly Lord, and the ties of affection and blood are too strong for any
but an outsider to reach the bottom of the plot. The players will have to use both brains and brawn to survive, and in the process, will witness how Chaos can subvert even the noblest of sentiments.

70148.name: Shadows in the Woods
70148.description:
User description:
The fourth installment of a living campaign, and fourth place in the 2009 Strike to Stun Scenario Contest, Shadows in the Woods is a rural investigation scenario examining the effects of isolation and the corruption of chaos.

70149.description:
In Ora et Labora, each player is head of a monastery in the Medieval era who acquires land and constructs buildings – little enterprises that will gain resources and profit. The goal is to build a working infrastructure and manufacture prestigious items – such as books, ceramics, ornaments, and relics – to gain the most victory points at the end of the game.

Ora et Labora, Uwe Rosenberg's fifth "big" game, has game play mechanisms similar to his Le Havre, such as two-sided resource tiles that can be upgraded from a basic item to something more useful. Instead of adding resources to the board turn by turn as in Agricola and Le Havre, Ora et Labora uses a numbered rondel to show how many of each resource is available at any time. At the beginning of each round, players turn the rondel by one segment, adjusting the counts of all resources at the same time.

Each player has a personal game board. New buildings enter the game from time to time, and players can construct them on their game boards with the building materials they gather, with some terrain restrictions on what can be built where. Some spaces start with trees or moors on them, as in Agricola: Farmers of the Moor, so they hinder development until a player clears the land, but they provide resources when they are removed. Clever building on your personal game board will impact your final score, and players can buy additional terrain during the game, if needed.

Players also have three workers who can enter buildings to take the action associated with that location. Workers must stay in place until you've placed all three. You can enter your own buildings with these workers, but to enter and use another player's buildings, you must pay that player an entry fee so that he'll move one of his workers into that building to do the work for you.

Ora et Labora features two variants: France and Ireland.
70149.name: Ora et Labora

70150.description:
Clara is abstract connection game similar to hex or twixt, but stones are placed (drawing) freely on board.

Similar as in hex or twist, players place stones (draw circle) on board and goal is connect oposite sides of board. Two near (max 2 diameters) stones are connected and connection is draw. Connections cannot be crossed. Stones cannot overlap.

Game can be played as paper and pencil game, but play on computer is far simpler. Length of game is dependent on size of stones (circles).

Version: Stones can overlap, but new stones (circles) are drawn under old circles.
70150.name: Clara

70151.name: Monster Knowledge Cards Volume 4—Animals & Vermin
70151.description:
From the publisher:

GM's Aid VI: Monster Knowledge Cards Volume 4—Animals & Vermin is the final release in the Monster Knowledge Cards line! Now, your Monster Knowledge Cards set can be complete!

With GM's Aid VI: Monster Knowledge Cards Volume 4—Animals & Vermin your job as GM just got easier. There is a card for each of the OGL animals and vermin in the SRD and each includes a number of facts about that particular creature. Each fact is tied to an increasingly higher Knowledge check DC. For Animals & Vermin, facts about real-world species have been included to add depth to these creatures. When the players characters are faced with a creature, whip out the appropriate card, have the players make rolls, and then consult the card to tell them what they know.

The cards have been formatted to print on any standard-size business card paper, or you can just print them on cardstock and cut them out using the lines as guides.

total cards: 12

70152.name: Monster Knowledge Card Volume 3 - Pegasus to Zombie
70152.description:
From the publisher:

GM's Aid V: Monster Knowledge Cards Volume 3 - Pegasus to Zombie is the fifth product in the GM's Aid line and third product in the Monster Knowledge Cards line from 4 Winds Fantasy Gaming. The cards have been designed as a game aid for players and gamemasters alike.

total cards: 16

70153.name: Watch Your Six: Aerial Combat in The Great War
70153.description:
Author: Michael J. Clinton

Squadron Level Air Combat Rules Aerial Combat in the Great War WATCH YOUR SIX ! is an in depth hex based game of squadron level air combat that took place on the Western Front during the Great War.
Emphasis is placed on outcomes rather than processes.
Unlike similar games, these rules were designed to allow a single player to handle multiple aircraft.
Pilot skill is just as important as the characteristics of the aircraft flown.
The WATCH YOUR SIX! rules are not a stand alone product.
Two sample aircraft and a single scenario are included in the rules set.

Expanded by YANKS!

Source: wy6 site: http://www.wy6.us)

70154.name: Iconic Character: Taelia
70154.description:
A deck of cards.
From the website:You're Taelia, a child of frost-rimmed magic; you hail from the Glintspar Mts. upon Ai, where magic is the basis of life. A master of ice and stone, you venture into the Untold, a brilliant L'na Dawn warrior-mystic who's more than capable of handling herself!

70155.name: Iconic Character: Apenimon
70155.description:
A deck of cards.

From the website:You're Apenimon, a mighty L'na Twilight mentalist who hails from the magic-laced world of Ai. You use your skills of mind and morph, tooth and claw (the mysterious Child of Zu powers) as you journey deep into the Untold on a voyage of discovery and danger!

70156.name: Powers: Gifts of Oaze
70156.description:
A deck of cards.

From the website:Gain the Gifts of Oaze! With this single, massive deck of Power cards, your character will gain bone-shattering attacks, stone-solid defenses, fantastical movement, and tremendous healing abilities. All you need do is accept the Untold gifts granted by the Investiture of Oaze!

70158.name: Powers: Clockwork Components
70158.description:
A deck of cards.

From the website:Gear up with Clockwork Components! Got a Klik or Steampunk-ish character that needs an overhaul? Step right up! This jam-packed deck contains over 54 gear-grinding powers, all brimming with Untold potential; more than enough to keep your clock wound and your gears a'turning!

70159.name: Environment: Mountains
70159.description:
A deck of cards.

From the website:With this awesome, 17 card booster, avalanches will be the least of your problems! Jam-packed with the minions and powers you need to populate the Untold mountains in your game, inside you'll meet the noble Draftrider, the stone-boned Deepdigger, Living Lightning, and tons more!

70160.name: Environment: Ruins
70160.description:
A deck of cards.

From the website:Get ready to rock some Ruins! This 17 card booster contains a ton of Untold goodness--definitely what you need to populate those creepy, deserted ruins in your game: Roving Maws, Darkstalkers, Crag Crawlers, Howling Horrors and more! Make 'em afraid of the dark all over again!

70161.name: Powers: Undead Infection Powers
70161.description:
A deck of cards.

From the website:The stuff of Nightmares! As if the horrid Undead Infection weren't bad enough already, now you can make them even worse with this 17(+) card Booster! Power Cards like Feed on the Dead, Grayfly Swarm, and of course, Undead Infection serve to make your Players dread the Undead!

70162.name: Powers: Undead Infection Powers
70162.description:
A deck of cards.

From the website:The stuff of Nightmares! As if the horrid Undead Infection weren't bad enough already, now you can make them even worse with this 17(+) card Booster! Power Cards like Feed on the Dead, Grayfly Swarm, and of course, Undead Infection serve to make your Players dread the Undead!

70163.name: Powers: NAU Defender Powers
70163.description:
A deck of cards.

From the website:Power up your NAU! Don't let your North American Union soldiers head into battle without this awesome Power Booster Pack at their sides! Basic Commando Training, Evasive Guard, Fireteam Attack, cool new Grenade Power Cards & more can be yours! Unleash the Untold fury of the NAU!

70164.name: Powers (Core): Melee Weapons
70164.description:
A deck of cards.

From the website:Time to do some DAMAGE! With this 17 pack of Power Cards, your character will never be without the means to waylay some Untold and massive damage their foes! All the basics: axes, bows, blades, chain-whips, clubs and more!

70165.name: Powers (Core): Melee Weapons
70165.description:
A deck of cards.

From the website:Time to do some DAMAGE! With this 17 pack of Power Cards, your character will never be without the means to waylay some Untold and massive damage their foes! All the basics: axes, bows, blades, chain-whips, clubs and more!

70166.name: Powers (Core): Melee Weapons
70166.description:
A deck of cards.

From the website:Time to do some DAMAGE! With this 17 pack of Power Cards, your character will never be without the means to waylay some Untold and massive damage their foes! All the basics: axes, bows, blades, chain-whips, clubs and more!

70167.name: Powers: Apoc Amplifications
70167.description:
A deck of cards.

From the website:Time to ramp up and amp up! This 53(+) deck of Apoc-oriented powers is what being an Apoc is all about: genetic-enhancements for the super solider survivor you wanna become! Everything from Adrenalin Push to Take the Pain can be found inside--and that's just the beginning!

70169.name: Bad Beginnings: Alpha
70169.description:
From publisher blurb:

Bad Beginnings is an Untold adventure that is playable by 4 to 6 Untold Characters of Untold Point (UP) values from 40 to 60 (we recommend starting at 45 UP). The purpose of the adventure is to provide an introduction to not only the Untold CBRPGTM as a whole and its unique card-based mechanics, but also to the default campaign setting of Untold, Splintered Serenity.

This adventure is broken down into three main standalone parts (Alpha, Beta and Gamma) which can be played in conjunction with one another, or with other "sideline" adventures interspersed between the three parts. However, Bad Beginnings is linear, and should be played as such. That is to say, it's okay to play Bad Beginnings - Alpha and then play several additional smaller adventures before moving on to Bad Beginnings - Beta, but it would NOT be possible (without a fair amount of re-work on the part of the GM) to play Bad Beginnings - Beta before playing Bad Beginnings - Alpha.

Bad Beginnings - Alpha itself consists of three main sections: answering an unusual call by traveling to a strange location known only as "The Crossroads"; extracting information from a lonely and dejected Klik Crucible in "Gear Grease" and finally a mixed-up and chaotic combat scenario in the final section of the adventure, entitled "Anomaly Extraction".

To play this adventure in Untold you will need to have characters either from the Starter Set, or ones you build from your own decks, and the GM will have to have the Bad Beginnings - Alpha deck that supports this adventure.

70171.name: Champions Mini-Series (Issue 1 - Jun 1986)
70171.description:
User Summary...

Comic book portion:
In this issue, the Fabulous Foxbat working for DEMON, is foiled in his attempt to steal a powerful artifact. Over the course of the issue the eponymous Champions assemble. This is complicated by the fact that Giant, the team's strongman, has to be dragged out of semi-retirement. The plot ends on a cliffhanger with DEMON attempting to steal the artifact from Champions in a direct assault on their base.

RPG Content:
Champions Combat Room #1 by Robert Pack & Dan Whitney
Raze [character write-up] by Peter Batterton
Flare [character write-up based on character created by Stacy Laurence] uncredited
Foxbat [character write-up based on character created by Bruce Harlick] uncredited
Champion Comments by Steve Peterson

70172.description:
Strategic board game, 2 armies of mercenaries are fighting for control of the city.

Players take on the 2 sides of the conflict. Struggle for dominance over each point of the city - buildings, special points, etc.

Players will acquire victory points for each building under their control.

The board represents the abandoned areas of cities. Attacking units will be coming up a city of eight pages. To realize there will be many missions and scenarios prepared for the modes: standard deathmatch, capture the region, capture the flag, deathmatch and cooperative.
70172.name: MERCENARY: Battle for City

70173.name: Blasphemous Cults
70173.description:
user summary:

This document presents an in character resource for Warhammer Fantasy Roleplay examining the existence of the Cults of Tzeentch. Also includes WFRP2 Characteristics for mentioned NPCs, plus other rules and plot hooks for using the material.

70174.description:
travel version of Mikado game; involves avoiding (or winning) colored little balls that will fall through after the Mikado stick have been pulled out of the stack. The stack is still kind of random, but is now fixed in a cilinder,that allows for playing on any surface (allthough playing in the back of a car might prove a bit difficult)

user sunmmary:
24 sticks are put through little holes in a cilinder, thereby creating some kind of 'net' blocking the opening of the cilinder. 17 blue balls and 1 yellow ball are poured over and are effectively blocked.
Then players may retreive a stick from the cilinder, 1 by 1, trying to avoid (or in a variant: to maximise) the number of balls falling through. The blue balls count for 1 and the yellow ball counts for 5 points. Balls lying on top of the stack of sticks may be manipulated when in the process of retreiving a stick, thereby forcing of preventing them from falling through.

It's a fun little game played by 2 to 4 players. Children like the colours and the balls falling through.
70174.name: Mikado Reisspel

70175.name: The Bridge on the River Reik
70175.description:
"A simple job as a merchants guards suddenly brings the players into a lot of trouble". A rural scenario designed for a single session of play, dealing with noble families disputing the ownership of a bridge.

-Quote from Strike to Stun

70176.name: There is something about Marié
70176.description:
There’s Something About Marié is a scenario suitable for characters of any experience level that can be run independently or as an interlude in a longer campaign like The Thousand Thrones. For the purposes of the scenario it is assumed that the Player Characters are travelling in a river barge along one of the tributaries of the great River Reik, but could be placed along any river within Sigmar’s Empire and with a little work even the river can be replaced with a road if the PCs are more of the footslogging persuasion.

The scenario consists of four chapters and its structure is directed by a few key events and the Player Characters’ choices rather than any preset plot. First, some background and a brief synopsis are given, followed by the actual adventure. Finally, descriptions of all the key NPCs, guidelines for awarding experience, and handouts conclude the scenario. In addition to the core rulebook Tome of Corruption would be useful, but not mandatory since all the necessary information for running the scenario is provided.

70177.description:
DBACW is an expansion for the WRG De Bellis Antiquitatis rules version 2.0 adapting the DBA mechanics to the American Civil War. Ownership of the DBA rules are required.

While the system is designed as an expansion to DBA, there are grades for troop types ("Veteran", "Experience", and "Raw") and Generals ("Good", "Average" and "Poor"), which is more similar to De Bellis Multitudinus (DBM). A typical army is a division composed of multiple brigades (each of which has its own commander). Rules are also given for larger battles forming Corps sized units.

Scale:
Infantry element: 4-500 men
Cavalry element: 3-400 men
Artillery element: 8-12 guns
Ground scale: 1" = 100 paces (about 80 yards)
70177.name: DBACW: An ACW Supplement for DBA Rules

70178.description:
The battle of little heroes continues, but now they get really evil: At this basic game you control rogues & scoundrels.
"Little Heroes - rogue & scoundrel" is a fast action card game.
Scenarios, evil deamons and 180 brand new card will bring you lots of fun in the world of little heroes!

This is a stand alone game, but of course you can combine it with the other games of little heroes for more fun.

Players each control a party of 2 different fantasy stereotype heroes (or scoundrels). They obtain cards which allow them to acquire equipment, potions and combat moves during the course of the game to help them try eliminating all other characters. The last hero still alive wins.
70178.name: Kleine Helden: Schurken & Halunken

70179.description:
Issue game of Game Link #2.
Designed by Yasutaka Ikeda.
Light card game of fantasy adventure.
Including characters, terrains, monsters, events, skills, items.

92 cards and tokens for characters, money, skills.

The game describes the characters' adventures in the world where the witchking controls.
Play actually proceeds with rolling dice and moving your character according to the roll then resolve the adventure card there. The terrain and your skill will affect the adventure card. You can get some money, item, or skill when you win the monster arose from the adventure card.

The character must collect 15 golds, or 3 emblems or eliminate the witchking to win the game.

Playable in an hour or so.
70179.name: Kingdom

70180.name: Innovation Planner
70180.description:
From the publisher web site:

"Innovation Planner(TM) is a card set of innovation strategies and solutions used for rapid, effective, and efficient problem solving and idea generation. It is based on the Ideation TRIZ innovation methodology that was derived from the analysis of over 3 million patents and 500 standard patterns of technical evolution. Just as you can combine the 26 letters in the alphabet to produce all ranges of literature, these cards describe the universal principles of invention that innovators combine to create the millions of inventions known to mankind.

You can use Innovation Planner(TM) for systematic innovation planning, brainstorming, or to play one of several innovation games. Use of this product as directed leads to the creation of new and patentable inventions. Inventors from using organizations have filed for dozens of patents inspired by the ideas on these cards, making these cards worth exponentially more than their weight in gold for the owning organizations."

See: http://www.innovationplannercards.com/.

Innovation Planner represents a set of cards to aid in brainstorming. The publishers also provide simple rules for two games, Solve It(TM) and Evolve It(TM), that utilize the cards.

In the games, a problem to solve is selected by players. Players are dealt cards. Each player plays a card on their turn. When a card is played by a player, the player attempts to use the information on the card to address the problem. The player then draws a new card. Play continues until the cards run out or the problem is addressed to the satisfaction of the players.

The goal of the card set and games is to innovate novel solutions to known issues, or to generate inventive ideas, which might be patentable.

70181.name: Mario Golf: Toadstool Tour

videogamefranchise.6395: Player's Choice (Best Selling Nintendo Games, US & EU)

videogamehonor.30948: 2004 Spike Best Handheld/Mobile Game of the Year Nominee

70181.description:
"Mario Golf: Toadstool Tour, known in Japan as Mario Golf: Family Tour (マリオゴルフ ファミリーツアー), is a sports game developed by Camelot Software Planning and published by Nintendo for the Nintendo GameCube. It is the sequel to the 1999 Nintendo 64 title Mario Golf, and is the fifth game in the Mario Golf series. It was released in North America on July 29, 2003, in Japan on September 5, 2003, and in the PAL region on June 18, 2004.

Toadstool Tour is a golf game featuring characters and elements from the Mario series. There are 16 playable characters in total, each with a set of golfing statistics defining their style of play. The game's main mode involves the player competing in tournaments to obtain new features, although there are alternative modes consisting of training session and variations to the golf format. This includes "Ring Attack", requiring the player to hit the ball through rings of varying sizes while remaining on or under par. Players can transfer characters between Mario Golf: Toadstool Tour and Mario Golf: Advance Tour using the Nintendo GameCube Game Boy Advance Cable.

Toadstool Tour received a positive reception from the media, gaining an aggregate score of 82% from Game Rankings. In general, reviewers praised the game's visuals, sound, and variety of courses, although a perceived lack of advancement from its predecessor was criticised. The game became part of the Player's Choice label in 2004.

This game marked the first appearance of a character from the Donkey Kong Country series (aside from the title character) in a Mario game: Diddy Kong (other DKC characters would go on to be featured in other Mario sports games later on)."

Source: Wikipedia, "Mario_Golf:_Toadstool_Tour," available under the CC-BY-SA License.

70182.name: Mario Golf: Advance Tour

videogamehonor.32655: 2006 British Academy Game Awards Best Sports Game of the Year Nominee

70182.description:
"Mario Golf: Advance Tour, known in Japan as Mario Golf: GBA Tour (マリオゴルフ ＧＢＡツアー), is an RPG-styled sports game developed by Camelot Software Planning and published by Nintendo for the Game Boy Advance in 2004. The game is the sequel to the Game Boy Color version of Mario Golf. The music was composed by Motoi Sakuraba."

Source: Wikipedia, "Mario_Golf:_Advance_Tour," available under the CC-BY-SA License.

70183.name: Mario Superstar Baseball

videogamefranchise.6395: Player's Choice (Best Selling Nintendo Games, US & EU)

70183.description:
"Mario Superstar Baseball (スーパーマリオスタジアム ミラクルベースボール, Sūpā Mario Sutajiamu Mirakuru Bēsubōru, lit. Super Mario Stadium Miracle Baseball) is a sports game that was developed by Namco and NOW Production and published by Nintendo for the Nintendo GameCube in 2005. The game was created in the vein of other Mario sports games such as Mario Golf: Toadstool Tour and Mario Power Tennis. This game is now a Player's Choice title. The game has a sequel, Mario Super Sluggers for the Wii."

Source: Wikipedia, "Mario_Superstar_Baseball," available under the CC-BY-SA License.

70184.name: Aprile 1945 L'ultima battaglia (the last battle)
70184.description: Operational wargame about the last month of WWII in Italy. One player is the German with some Fascist allies trying to delay allied advance toward the Po river. The other player has the composite forces of the Allies (American, British, Commonwealth, Polish, Jewish, Brazilian and Italian) with the objective to pierce enemy lines, catch significant cities and block retreat roads to the river and to Germany. Allies have a mighty airpower, while German has multiple defence lines with improved positions and a plenty of minor rivers. Rules reflect initial Hitler's strategy to hold until last man and, for the Allies, logistic problems to launch two main offensives at once; so German has initial movement limits and Allies must wait some game turns for their attacks: first the British Army,then the American Army.

70185.name: Whirled Peas
70185.description:
In Whirled Peas, players compete in two teams in five types of interactive challenges, with the winner of each challenge earning a pea to fill its team pod. The first team to fill its pod wins. The challenges are:

• Putty Pal: Manipulate someone's body to act out the hidden word.
• Back Tracks: Draw an object on a teammate's back.
• Zip Your Lip: Get teammates to guess a word/phrase through charades and talking – but only talking through a closed mouth.
• Sketch Coach: Give drawing instructions to players on both teams and hope your team can guess the answer first.
• Clap Trap: One player from each team face off, giving answers to a category back and forth until one player falters. The other players clap. No, really.

70186.name: Mario Super Sluggers

videogamefranchise.11430: Nintendo Selects (Best Selling Wii Games, US & EU)

70186.description:
"Mario Super Sluggers, known in Japan as Super Mario Stadium Family Baseball (スーパーマリオスタジアム ファミリーベースボール), is a sports video game for the Wii developed by Namco Bandai and published by Nintendo. It was previously known by the working title Super Mario Stadium Baseball. It is part of the Mario Sports series, and the sequel to Mario Superstar Baseball for the Nintendo GameCube. Mario Super Sluggers was released in Japan on June 19, 2008 and in North America on August 25, 2008."

Source: Wikipedia, "Mario_Super_Sluggers," available under the CC-BY-SA License.

70187.name: Super Mario Strikers

videogamefranchise.6395: Player's Choice (Best Selling Nintendo Games, US & EU)

videogamehonor.29839: 2006 D.I.C.E. Best Sports Game of the Year Nominee

70187.description:
"Super Mario Strikers, known as Mario Smash Football in Europe and Australia, is a five-a-side football game developed by Next Level Games for the Nintendo GameCube. The game was released in Europe and North America in late 2005, and in Japan and Australia in 2006. The game's sequel, Mario Strikers Charged, was also developed by Next Level games and is available for the Wii. The game's developers had worked on the NHL series before development of Strikers, which served as an influence for the fast-paced and physical nature of the game.

Strikers is a sports game game incorporating characters and themes from the Mario series. The game features the basic aspects and objectives of a football game, although no referees are present and characters can legitimately shove others out of possession of the ball. As in other games such as Mario Power Tennis, the player can use Mario-themed items such as bananas and red shells to hinder the opposition and gain the advantage. Each team's captain can also use "Super Strikes" that, if timed accurately, will result in two points scored for the striker's team. Each team comprises a goal keeper, a main Mario character (captain), and three of the same secondary Mario characters known as "side kicks".

The game received a positive reaction from the media, attaining an aggregate score of 76 percent from Game Rankings. In general, reviewers lauded Striker's accessibility and multiplayer gameplay, but criticised the lack of gameplay modes and single-player offerings."

Source: Wikipedia, "Super_Mario_Strikers," available under the CC-BY-SA License.

70188.name: Darwin's Finches
70188.description:
On September 15 1835, HMS Beagle on its second surveying voyage arrived at the Galapagos Islands. On board was a young geologist by the name of Charles Darwin. Over the next five weeks, the ship visited four of the islands of the archipelago. During these visits, Darwin collected 37 bird specimens he thought unique. While traveling home, Darwin pondered the variations in beak size of the mockingbirds and finches he had collected. These slight variations in beak structure, along with other small differences observed in both plants and animals he collected, were the beginnings of a radical new thought in how species came to exist. Over the next fourteen years, Darwin expanded upon these ideas ultimately publishing his controversial treatise The Origin of Species in 1859.

In this game, players help four species of finch evolve and spread throughout the Galapagos archipelago from one common ancestor. Species evolve and migrate as they try to dominate the habitable population centers on the islands. Each species of finch has a preferred habitat, ground or tree, and preferred food source, insects or seeds. Players can affect the dominate species by increasing the food source or habitat type of a particular species. At the game end, the player who has the most valuable finch collection is declared the winner.

70189.name: Mario Strikers Charged

videogamefranchise.11430: Nintendo Selects (Best Selling Wii Games, US & EU)

70189.description:
"Mario Strikers Charged, known as Mario Strikers Charged Football in PAL regions, is a sports video game developed by Canadian developer Next Level Games and published by Nintendo for the Wii. This game was announced at the 2006 Games Convention in Leipzig, Germany as the sequel to Super Mario Strikers for the Nintendo GameCube. It was released on May 25, 2007 in Europe, June 7, 2007 in Australia and July 30, 2007 in North America.

The game supports the Nintendo Wi-Fi Connection, through which players can participate in online matches and tournaments. Upon its European release, it became the first Wii online game to be available outside of Japan."

Source: Wikipedia, "Mario_Strikers_Charged," available under the CC-BY-SA License.

70190.name: Colonial Gothic Gazetteer
70190.description:
From the publisher:

It is 1775.

The conflict between the American colonists and the British Parliament has come to a head at Boston. War seems inevitable. Behind the war, unseen hands move unknowing pieces, manipulating events according to ancient plans. Beside the war, ghosts and monsters walk the land and ancient curses run their course.

Welcome to the Thirteen Colonies.

In this book you will find maps and information covering each of the Thirteen Colonies, plus the Province of Maine and local native peoples, plus a short ready-to-play adventure, A Surprise for General Gage. A glossary explains unfamiliar terms both native and colonial, and a bibliography points to more detailed information on the colonies and their inhabitants.

Written by Graeme Davis, this book is your guide to the Thirteen Colonies. Filled with maps, adventure hooks, and other information, this book picks up were Colonial Gothic Revised left off, and begins exploring the world of Colonial Gothic.

70191.name: Newsies & Pickpockets
70191.description:
Being a game of imagination, role-playing and wonder by Miguel de Luis, on the adventures of a bunch of kids earning their pluck by their own in an Edwardian world filled with crazed inventors, fagins, strange conspiracies and exotic foreigners from countries you never heard about and an ounce of steampunk.

(source: handbook)

70192.name: Mario's Tennis
70192.description:
"Mario's Tennis (マリオズテニス) is a game for Nintendo's Virtual Boy video game console. Also known by its working title Mario's Dream Tennis, it was the console's pack-in game in North America. The game features eight famous characters from the Mario series. Although a two-player function was announced, it was not implemented since the cable required to link two Virtual Boy units was never released. Due to the Virtual Boy's poor sales in North America, Mario's Tennis did not become as popular as the other games in the Mario Tennis series."

Source: Wikipedia, "Mario's_Tennis," available under the CC-BY-SA License.

70193.name: Mario Tennis (N64)

videogamefranchise.6395: Player's Choice (Best Selling Nintendo Games, US & EU)

videogamehonor.30115: 2001 D.I.C.E. Best Family Game of the Year Winner (Console)

70193.description:
"Mario Tennis (マリオテニス64, Mario Tenisu Rokujūyon, Mario Tennis 64) is a sports video game published Nintendo and developed by Camelot Software Planning for the Nintendo 64 video game console. The game was released in North America and Japan in the summer of 2000, and released in Europe later in November. It is the first tennis-oriented game starring Mario since Mario's Tennis, and the first game developed by Camelot on a Nintendo system.

The success of Mario Tennis led to a sequel, Mario Power Tennis in 2004."

Source: Wikipedia, "Mario_Tennis_(video_game)," available under the CC-BY-SA License.

70194.name: Sprach-Schatz
70194.description:
Each player has a letter grid on a sheet of paper. The players roll dice and move onto letter squares on which they have to solve word puzzles (supplied on question cards). If they succeed, they can write the letter in any position in their grid. The goal is to fill the grid with four words across (different length as shown on the grid) and one down.
There are some fields on the board which allow players to erase letters when they wrote them in wrong positions.

(User summary by HilkMAN)

70195.name: International Cricket
70195.description: Dice based cricket game, The box folds out into a cricket ground, and both players have an elastic band powered catapult they use to "throw" the dice into the box. With the dice results either resulting with runs scored or a wicket.

70196.name: Mario Power Tennis

videogamefranchise.11430: Nintendo Selects (Best Selling Wii Games, US & EU)

videogamehonor.29787: 2005 D.I.C.E. Best Sports Game of the Year Nominee (Console)

70196.description:
"Mario Power Tennis, known in Japan as Mario Tennis GC (マリオテニスGC), is a sports game developed by Camelot Software Planning and published by Nintendo for the Nintendo GameCube in 2004. The game is the sequel to the Nintendo 64 title Mario Tennis, and is the fourth game in the Mario Tennis series. Power Tennis was released in Japan on October 28, 2004, in North America on November 8, 2004, and in Australia on February 25, 2005. The game was re-released for the Wii in 2009 as part of the New Play Control! collection of titles, featuring GameCube games with added Wii controls.

Power Tennis incorporates multiple characters, themes, and locations from the Mario series. The game includes standard tennis matches, but contains variants that feature different scoring formats and objectives. Other variants include "Gimmick" courts, thematic areas with components and properties that directly affect gameplay. The game consists of 18 playable characters, each categorised by their style of play and each with a pair of unique moves known as "Power Shots". Power Tennis was developed simultaneously with Mario Golf: Toadstool Tour, and the pair shared similar technology and concepts with each other during production. Such similarities include an emphasis on the Mario theme in characters and settings as well as alternative game modes such as "Ring Shot"."

Source: Wikipedia, "Mario_Power_Tennis," available under the CC-BY-SA License.

70197.description:
This is a Disney "Mickey Mouse Clubhouse" game for preschool children. It is designed for kids age 3 and older with no reading required. The game can accomodate up to four children who portray Mickey, Minnie, Goofy, or Donald Duck as they move around a colorful board.

A special die is used with colors instead of numbers. Players journey around the board as they learn colors, counting, taking turns, being required to stop during a move, and other basic skills.

Includes the board, 4 stand-up tokens, the special die, and rules.

Cardinal Item # 37169
70197.name: Silly Switch Game

70198.name: Knights of the Dinner Table Magazine (Issue 71 - Sep 2002)

rpgissuearticle.59411: An A.C.E. in the Hole -  Starting Life as a Kid. Again.

70198.description:
"Four Angry Men"

Cover by George Vrbanic and Jackie Vrbanic

The Table of Contents moved to a clearer two-column format.

The table of contents is detailed in the Article list below.

70199.name: Mario Tennis: Power Tour
70199.description:
"Mario Tennis: Power Tour (マリオテニスアドバンス, Mario Tenisu Adobansu, Mario Tennis Advance), released in Europe as Mario Power Tennis, is a sports game developed by Camelot Software Planning and published by Nintendo for the Game Boy Advance in 2005. It is the sequel to the Game Boy Color version of Mario Tennis. However, unlike Mario Tennis, players cannot hook their game up with the respective Nintendo GameCube version."

Source: Wikipedia, "Mario_Tennis:_Power_Tour," available under the CC-BY-SA License.

70200.name: Fields of War
70200.description:
Publisher Blurb:

This tactical sourcebook explores the various theaters of the early days of the Alternate Second World War and the operations that took place in them. Fields of War contains numerous tactical scenario seeds for the Gear Krieg universe that can be played together or separately, along with sample strike forces and heroes, special rules and miniature modeling advice for both the tabletop and the Gear Krieg miniatures.

Fields of War includes:

- Rules for Natural, Urban and Combat Engineering tabletop features;
- Scenario seeds for the above environments;
- Modeling instructions for both the tabletop and miniatures;
- New Heroes and equipment for Germany, the British Commonwealth, the United States, Soviet Russia and Imperial Japan;
- and several new vehicles and variants.

A copy of the Gear Krieg Rulebook, a few six-sided dice, miniatures/counters, pen and paper are required to use this supplement.

70201.name: N-Gage Classic
70201.description:
The original phone's taco-shaped design was considered clumsy: to insert a game, users had to remove the phone's plastic cover and remove the battery compartment as the game slot was next to it. Another clumsy feature was the speaker and microphone being located on the side edge of the phone. This often resulted in many to describe it as if one was talking into a "taco phone" or "Sidetalking", or simply that they had one very large ear, because the user held the edge of the phone against the cheek in order to talk into it. The comfort factor of lengthy calls was also called into question. Despite the criticism, it is thought that the speakers were there for a practical reason: if placed elsewhere, the screen would get in contact with the cheek and become smudged. However, almost all other cell phones have the screen against the cheek when the user is talking. Despite the questionable practicality, gamers were still unwilling to talk in such an awkward manner.

When considered from a video game point of view, the N-Gage was known for its unusual screen orientation, a vertical one as opposed to a horizontal one (which is more popular with other handhelds). The reason for this was that the underlying operating system, Series 60, did not support horizontal orientations at that time (only supported since S60v3 ). Some felt this to be a negative feature, feeling that 'unconventional' does not necessarily mean improvement. Possibly due to this screen feature, as well as the public's luke-warm reception to the device, the game library was far from extensive. Despite this, the N-Gage did manage to garner some well known franchises such as Tomb Raider, Sonic, Rayman, Red Faction, Tony Hawk's Pro Skater, The Elder Scrolls, among others.

Source: Wikipedia, "N-Gage", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

70202.name: N-Gage QD
70202.description:
The N-Gage QD is a handheld game console and mobile phone by Nokia, and the successor to the N-Gage. It was unveiled on April 14, 2004.

It revised the device's physical design, being smaller and rounder. It corrected the flaw of the cartridge slot with a more convenient one on the bottom of the device. This design also moved the earpiece to the face of the device, rather than on the side, as in the previous model.

Despite the revision, the unit drew quick criticism. Some noted that the rubber fitting side that closed the gap between the device top and bottom casing could be easily loosened over a few months. Once the rubber piece was removed, the device became more vulnerable to water or particles entering the internals unless the fitting was replaced. Replacement fittings were available at Nokia's service centers. Various third-party sellers also sold unofficial replacement fittings via online electronics suppliers or eBay.

The device retailed at a lower price compared to the original N-Gage device, aided by the fact that it was usually sold with service contracts and applicable subsidies. For instance, in the United States the N-Gage QD was available as a prepaid phone offered by Cingular for $99.99 at retail games stores such as Electronics Boutique and GameStop.

Source: Wikipedia, "N-Gage QD", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

70204.name: Dungeon Set 1
70204.description:
Publisher Blurb:

DRAGON TILES add a new dimension to boring miniature tiles...literally. We've combined 2D tiles with 3D props, allowing you to create a visually stunning tabletop for your players quickly and easily. This set includes 28 large 8"x8" tiles and enough 3D props to stock your dungeon. All props are designed for the novice card modeler and can be built in minutes. All art is created by award winning artists and is 300dpi for maximum detail.

This PDF includes:
28 Dungeon Tiles
"E-Z Fold"Doors
Wooden Crates
Treasure Chest (large, two styles)
Treasure Chest (small, two styles)
Weapons Rack
Wooden Table
Wooden Chairs
Wooden Bench
Treasure Tile (two styles)
Pit Trap Tile
Rope Bridged

70205.name: Dungeon Set 2
70205.description:
Publisher Blurb:
